text: Help your baby learn through play.  Put objects in your baby’s grasping hand, show them different materials, and answer when they ‘talk’ to you.
source_text: Help your baby learn through play.  Put objects in your baby’s grasping hand, show them different materials, and answer when they ‘talk’ to you.

text: Unfortunately, your baby will go through phases for the next 2 years of sleeping poorly. Try wearing your baby close to you, feeding them and carrying them in a sling. And hang in there, remember it’s a phase. You and your baby will get through it together!
source_text: Unfortunately, your baby will go through phases for the next 2 years of sleeping poorly. Try wearing your baby close to you, feeding them and carrying them in a sling. And hang in there, remember it’s a phase. You and your baby will get through it together!

text: Your baby will cry as soon as a caregiver’s attention is diverted and are cranky as well as clingy. Prioritise being there for them and give them physical contact when needed.
source_text: Your baby will cry as soon as a caregiver’s attention is diverted and are cranky as well as clingy. Prioritise being there for them and give them physical contact when needed.

text: Check to see why your baby is in a bad mood. Are they tired or hungry? Or maybe they are not feeling well? Or maybe they need some more loving attention. Be a reassuring presence for your baby when they are having a difficult day.
source_text: Check to see why your baby is in a bad mood. Are they tired or hungry? Or maybe they are not feeling well? Or maybe they need some more loving attention. Be a reassuring presence for your baby when they are having a difficult day.

text: Remember that you’re in charge of what they eat, but not how much. Newborns have stomach the size of a grape! They need to eat often (sometimes in the middle of the night.
source_text: Remember that you’re in charge of what they eat, but not how much. Newborns have stomach the size of a grape! They need to eat often (sometimes in the middle of the night.

text: It’s important to build trust around eating, especially as your baby starts on solid food. Let them know you are listening to their wishes in the eating department. They’ll be ravenous again soon!
source_text: It’s important to build trust around eating, especially as your baby starts on solid food. Let them know you are listening to their wishes in the eating department. They’ll be ravenous again soon!

text: Pay close attention to your baby in case they try something dangerous! Just because they are able to play on their own now, doesn’t mean you can look away for long. Redirect mischievous behaviours into practice waving, imitation games, singing and moving games and pretending to talk on the phone!
source_text: Pay close attention to your baby in case they try something dangerous! Just because they are able to play on their own now, doesn’t mean you can look away for long. Redirect mischievous behaviours into practice waving, imitation games, singing and moving games and pretending to talk on the phone!

text: Here are 4 simple steps that you can do when talking about COVID-19 with your children:
source_text: Here are 4 simple steps that you can do when talking about COVID-19 with your children:

text: 1. Be open, honest, and supportive
source_text: 1. Be open, honest, and supportive

text: 2. It is okay not to know the answers
source_text: 2. It is okay not to know the answers

text: 3. Be a hero not a bully
source_text: 3. Be a hero not a bully

text: 4. End on a good note
source_text: 4. End on a good note

text: Type "1" to "4" to learn more about each tip. Type "N" to stop this tip.
source_text: Type "1" to "4" to learn more about each tip. Type "N" to stop this tip.

text: That's okay! You can always type "Help" if you want to learn more about how to talk about COVID-19 with your child. Chat to you later!
source_text: That's okay! You can always type "Help" if you want to learn more about how to talk about COVID-19 with your child. Chat to you later!

text: Step 1. Be open, honest, and supportive
source_text: Step 1. Be open, honest, and supportive

text: Allow your child to talk freely. Ask them open questions and find out how much they already know.
source_text: Allow your child to talk freely. Ask them open questions and find out how much they already know.

text: Sorry I don't understand what you mean.
source_text: Sorry I don't understand what you mean.

text: n no
source_text: n no
note: This is an argument and it may be used to identify a corresponding quick reply

text: Always answer their questions truthfully. Think about how old your child is and how much they can understand.
source_text: Always answer their questions truthfully. Think about how old your child is and how much they can understand.

text: Your child may be scared or confused. Give them space to share how they are feeling and let them know you are there for them.
source_text: Your child may be scared or confused. Give them space to share how they are feeling and let them know you are there for them.

text: Step 2. It is OK not to know the answers.
source_text: Step 2. It is OK not to know the answers.

text: It is fine to say “We don’t know, but we are working on it; or we don’t know, ‘but we think’.”  Use this as an opportunity to learn something new with your child. The WHO and UNICEF websites are great first steps to learn.
source_text: It is fine to say “We don’t know, but we are working on it; or we don’t know, ‘but we think’.”  Use this as an opportunity to learn something new with your child. The WHO and UNICEF websites are great first steps to learn.

text: WHO: https://www.who.int/emergencies/diseases/novel-coronavirus-2019/advice-for-public
source_text: WHO: https://www.who.int/emergencies/diseases/novel-coronavirus-2019/advice-for-public

text: UNICEF: https://www.unicef.org/coronavirus/covid-19
source_text: UNICEF: https://www.unicef.org/coronavirus/covid-19

text: Step 3. Be a hero not a bully
source_text: Step 3. Be a hero not a bully

text: Explain that COVID-19 has nothing to do with the way someone looks, where they are from, or what language they speak.
source_text: Explain that COVID-19 has nothing to do with the way someone looks, where they are from, or what language they speak.

text: Step 4. End on a good note
source_text: Step 4. End on a good note

text: Check to see if your child is okay. Remind them that you care and that they can talk to you anytime. Then do something fun together!

text: Infant (0–1 year) needs:
source_text: Infant (0–1 year) needs:

text: • Us to provide food, sleep, cleaning, comfort and safety.
source_text: • Us to provide food, sleep, cleaning, comfort and safety.

text: • A strong bond with parent/ caregiver.
source_text: • A strong bond with parent/ caregiver.

text: • Lots of play and attention - the most active time of brain development is during the first 1000 days of life!
source_text: • Lots of play and attention - the most active time of brain development is during the first 1000 days of life!

text: Young children (4-6 years):
source_text: Young children (4-6 years):

text: • Same as toddlers, but also...
source_text: • Same as toddlers, but also...

text: • Learn through actions and play.
source_text: • Learn through actions and play.

text: • Develop friendships with other children
source_text: • Develop friendships with other children

text: • Find it difficult to separate make-believe from reality. Still express feelings in dramatic ways!
source_text: • Find it difficult to separate make-believe from reality. Still express feelings in dramatic ways!

text: Young teenagers (10-12 years)
source_text: Young teenagers (10-12 years)

text: • More interested in learning in school.
source_text: • More interested in learning in school.

text: • Start to want independence and trust.
source_text: • Start to want independence and trust.

text: • Want to spend time with other children and young teenagers.

text: • May be interested in religion or spirituality

text: Young teenagers (10-12 years)
source_text: Young teenagers (10-12 years)

text: • May answer back to adults to show that they “know”.

text: • Can be very self-conscious and sensitive
source_text: • Can be very self-conscious and sensitive

text: • Can learn to better manage anger and tolerate frustration.

text: Infants (0-1):
source_text: Infants (0-1):

text: • 0–6 months: Smile, babble and cry to attract your attention. We should provide care, cuddling and protection.
source_text: • 0–6 months: Smile, babble and cry to attract your attention. We should provide care, cuddling and protection.

text: • 6–11 months: Cling to you, especially when feeling insecure or frightened.
source_text: • 6–11 months: Cling to you, especially when feeling insecure or frightened.

text: • 12–23 months: Start to walk, talk and explore things around them!
source_text: • 12–23 months: Start to walk, talk and explore things around them!

text: Middle teenagers (13-14 years)
source_text: Middle teenagers (13-14 years)

text: • Begin to challenge adult rules
source_text: • Begin to challenge adult rules

text: • Are often insecure and confused.
source_text: • Are often insecure and confused.

text: • Feelings get hurt easily and have mood swings
source_text: • Feelings get hurt easily and have mood swings

text: • Try to be the boss and are unhappy if they lose.
source_text: • Try to be the boss and are unhappy if they lose.

text: Toddlers (2-3 years):
source_text: Toddlers (2-3 years):

text: • Become a curious little explorer - watch out for climbing!
source_text: • Become a curious little explorer - watch out for climbing!

text: • Learn through play and trying things out
source_text: • Learn through play and trying things out

text: • Want to learn how to do new things (like getting dressed) and make their own decisions.
source_text: • Want to learn how to do new things (like getting dressed) and make their own decisions.

text: • Want your praise and your approval
source_text: • Want your praise and your approval

text: Middle teenagers (13-14 years)
source_text: Middle teenagers (13-14 years)

text: • Their friends are important and affect their choices
source_text: • Their friends are important and affect their choices

text: • Need some freedom but also reliable rules that don't change
source_text: • Need some freedom but also reliable rules that don't change

text: • Need affection, reassurance, self-esteem, encouragement to believe in their abilities
source_text: • Need affection, reassurance, self-esteem, encouragement to believe in their abilities

text: Toddlers (2-3 years):
source_text: Toddlers (2-3 years):

text: • Start speaking in sentences and  learning new words.
source_text: • Start speaking in sentences and  learning new words.

text: • Does not like to lose or take turns, but sharing can be taught.
source_text: • Does not like to lose or take turns, but sharing can be taught.

text: • May express feelings in dramatic ways (like screaming on the floor!). Can start to learn how to manage their feelings.
source_text: • May express feelings in dramatic ways (like screaming on the floor!). Can start to learn how to manage their feelings.

text: Young children (4-6 years):
source_text: Young children (4-6 years):

text: • Does not like to lose, share or take turns, but losing and taking turns can be taught.

text: Step 1. Keep your child safe and well
source_text: Step 1. Keep your child safe and well

text: • Keep your country's COVID-19 rules, and also help your child to be active - do whatever exercise you can with them inside or outside your home
source_text: • Keep your country's COVID-19 rules, and also help your child to be active - do whatever exercise you can with them inside or outside your home

text: • Keep emergency contact numbers somewhere easy to see
source_text: • Keep emergency contact numbers somewhere easy to see

text: no n
source_text: no n
note: This is an argument and it may be used to identify a corresponding quick reply

text: Step 2. Try to understand how they are feeling
source_text: Step 2. Try to understand how they are feeling

text: • Your child may be feeling a lot of stress, anxiety, and frustration.
source_text: • Your child may be feeling a lot of stress, anxiety, and frustration.

text: • Tell them that you love them
source_text: • Tell them that you love them

text: • Praise them for being good and for trying to be good!
source_text: • Praise them for being good and for trying to be good!

text: Step 5. Make daily plans to help them feel secure
source_text: Step 5. Make daily plans to help them feel secure

text: • Having things that are the same each day helps children feel secure and safe.
source_text: • Having things that are the same each day helps children feel secure and safe.

text: • Make a daily plan that includes some things they like to do.
source_text: • Make a daily plan that includes some things they like to do.

text: • Help your child connect to friends and family members through phone, writing cards, or drawing pictures.
source_text: • Help your child connect to friends and family members through phone, writing cards, or drawing pictures.

text: • Give your child choices: this gives them a sense of control and builds self-esteem.
source_text: • Give your child choices: this gives them a sense of control and builds self-esteem.

text: • Use simple language and clear instructions. If words aren't good for them, try gestures and pictures.
source_text: • Use simple language and clear instructions. If words aren't good for them, try gestures and pictures.

text: Step 4. Praise them!
source_text: Step 4. Praise them!

text: • Praise them for behaving well, and for trying.
source_text: • Praise them for behaving well, and for trying.

text: • Focus on what they can do, not what they can't.
source_text: • Focus on what they can do, not what they can't.

text: • Only help children when they need it. It is also good to build independence!
source_text: • Only help children when they need it. It is also good to build independence!

text: Step 3. Talking and communicating with your child
source_text: Step 3. Talking and communicating with your child

text: • Get down to your child’s level when you speak.
source_text: • Get down to your child’s level when you speak.

text: • Look at them and smile
source_text: • Look at them and smile

text: • Give them time to tell you or show you what they think
source_text: • Give them time to tell you or show you what they think

text: • Tell your child that you understand
source_text: • Tell your child that you understand

text: Step 6. Ask for help if you can
source_text: Step 6. Ask for help if you can

text: • Share the load with other adult family members.
source_text: • Share the load with other adult family members.

text: •  You are not alone! Keep connected with people who understand your situation.
source_text: •  You are not alone! Keep connected with people who understand your situation.

text: • Share your challenges AND your successes.
source_text: • Share your challenges AND your successes.

text: • It is normal to feel stressed, frustrated, and afraid at this time.
source_text: • It is normal to feel stressed, frustrated, and afraid at this time.

text: • Be kind to yourself and take a break when you need to!
source_text: • Be kind to yourself and take a break when you need to!

text: Children and teens often act disrespectfully or like they only care about themselves. Growing up is a difficult time when they are learning about who they are and how they want to be in the world. Luckily, there are other ways to discipline your teen without using violence…and they work well!

Growing up is a difficult time when they are learning about who they are and how they want to be in the world. Luckily, there are other ways to discipline your teen without using violence…and they work well!

text: Giving calm consequences help teach our children responsibility for what they do. They also allow discipline that is controlled. This is more effective than hitting or shouting.

text: Here are 5 tips for using consequences:

text: 1. Give a choice before consequence

text: 2. Stay calm but be firm

text: 3. Be realistic and follow through

text: 5. Consequences for breaking rules
source_text: 5. Consequences for breaking rules

text: Consequences can also be used when your children forget a household rule, like going to bed at a certain hour or doing schoolwork before T.V.
source_text: Consequences can also be used when your children forget a household rule, like going to bed at a certain hour or doing schoolwork before T.V.

text: 4. Reconnect afterwards.
source_text: 4. Reconnect afterwards.

text: Once the consequence is over, give your child a chance to do something good, and praise them for it.
source_text: Once the consequence is over, give your child a chance to do something good, and praise them for it.

text: 2. Try to stay calm but firm when giving the consequence.
source_text: 2. Try to stay calm but firm when giving the consequence.

text: If you start yelling, it will just make things worse. Take a deep breath before you speak in a clear, calm, and firm voice.
source_text: If you start yelling, it will just make things worse. Take a deep breath before you speak in a clear, calm, and firm voice.

text: 3. Be realistic and follow through
source_text: 3. Be realistic and follow through

text: Make sure you can follow through with the consequence. For example, taking away a teenager’s phone for a week is hard to enforce. Taking it away for one hour is more realistic.
source_text: Make sure you can follow through with the consequence. For example, taking away a teenager’s phone for a week is hard to enforce. Taking it away for one hour is more realistic.

text: For example, you can tell your child that if they do not do their schoolwork before dinner, they cannot watch their favourite T.V. show that evening.
source_text: For example, you can tell your child that if they do not do their schoolwork before dinner, they cannot watch their favourite T.V. show that evening.

text: Here are some things you can do when your teen shares something difficult with you:
source_text: Here are some things you can do when your teen shares something difficult with you:

text: • Take a deep breath before you respond.
source_text: • Take a deep breath before you respond.

text: • Listen to what your child is saying. Notice how they are feeling.
source_text: • Listen to what your child is saying. Notice how they are feeling.

text: • Notice how you feel. Ask yourself, "What does my child need right now?"

text: • Reassure your child that you are there for them.

text: • You can deal with the consequences later but right now your child needs you.
source_text: • You can deal with the consequences later but right now your child needs you.

text: • Discuss possible solutions or next steps to take action.
source_text: • Discuss possible solutions or next steps to take action.

text: • Remind your child again that you love them and thank them for sharing with you.

text: The sound of a baby crying can be very distressing, especially for a parent. It is completely natural to want to make it stop. You might also think that you are not a good parent or that your baby is crying to spite you. But all babies cry. It is one of the main ways a baby can tell you that something is wrong.

text: 1. Why do babies cry?
source_text: 1. Why do babies cry?

text: Crying is a normal part of your baby's development. Sometimes babies even have crying patterns. Crying usually increases at 2-3 weeks old and is generally highest when your baby is around 6 to 8 weeks. Often babies will start crying less around 3 to 4 months. Of course, remember that every baby is different!
source_text: Crying is a normal part of your baby's development. Sometimes babies even have crying patterns. Crying usually increases at 2-3 weeks old and is generally highest when your baby is around 6 to 8 weeks. Often babies will start crying less around 3 to 4 months. Of course, remember that every baby is different!

text: 3.  Check to see why your baby is crying
source_text: 3.  Check to see why your baby is crying

text: There are lots of reasons why babies cry. It might be hunger, pain, too much going on, rough handling, feeling cold/hot, wanting contact or attention, or feeling irritable. Babies can cry when they sense tension in the room. And sometimes they cry for no reason at all!
source_text: There are lots of reasons why babies cry. It might be hunger, pain, too much going on, rough handling, feeling cold/hot, wanting contact or attention, or feeling irritable. Babies can cry when they sense tension in the room. And sometimes they cry for no reason at all!

text: no n
source_text: no n
note: This is an argument and it may be used to identify a corresponding quick reply

text: 4. Comfort your baby
source_text: 4. Comfort your baby

text: Try swaddling, gently rocking, or singing or soft music. You might need to feed your baby or change their diaper. They may be too hot or too cold. Or maybe they just need to be held. Take a Pause and try to relax - your baby can actually sense tension from you, too!
source_text: Try swaddling, gently rocking, or singing or soft music. You might need to feed your baby or change their diaper. They may be too hot or too cold. Or maybe they just need to be held. Take a Pause and try to relax - your baby can actually sense tension from you, too!

text: 7. If you think your baby is injured or sick, call or visit a clinic
source_text: 7. If you think your baby is injured or sick, call or visit a clinic

text: If your baby cries for a long time and does not stop, they might be injured or sick. You should seek medical help immediately.
source_text: If your baby cries for a long time and does not stop, they might be injured or sick. You should seek medical help immediately.

text: 6. Be gentle and patient with yourself
source_text: 6. Be gentle and patient with yourself

text: We know that this is not easy. You are not a bad parent if your baby continues to cry after you have done all they can to calm them. You are doing your best!
source_text: We know that this is not easy. You are not a bad parent if your baby continues to cry after you have done all they can to calm them. You are doing your best!

text: 2. Respond as soon as you can
source_text: 2. Respond as soon as you can

text: Go to your baby when you hear them crying. You will not spoil your baby by picking them up. Babies who are carried and cuddled frequently, during both fussy and contented periods, may actually cry less.
source_text: Go to your baby when you hear them crying. You will not spoil your baby by picking them up. Babies who are carried and cuddled frequently, during both fussy and contented periods, may actually cry less.

text: Well done! You have added another skill to your Parenting Toolkit. Remember that there are no bad parents. We are all learning here!
source_text: Well done! You have added another skill to your Parenting Toolkit. Remember that there are no bad parents. We are all learning here!

text: 5. Take a break!
source_text: 5. Take a break!

text: If you are getting angry because your baby won’t stop crying, it’s OK to leave them on their back in a safe place and walk away for a bit. Check on your baby every 5-10 minutes.
source_text: If you are getting angry because your baby won’t stop crying, it’s OK to leave them on their back in a safe place and walk away for a bit. Check on your baby every 5-10 minutes.

text: Call someone for help - a family member, a friend. Sometimes just talking with someone is enough, but if you feel overwhelmed, ask someone for help. Calling for help is a sign of strength.
source_text: Call someone for help - a family member, a friend. Sometimes just talking with someone is enough, but if you feel overwhelmed, ask someone for help. Calling for help is a sign of strength.

text: Here are some tips for how we can help our children learn how to cope with their emotions:

text: 1. Be open to your child
source_text: 1. Be open to your child

text: Your child will look to you for support and reassurance. Listen to your children when they share how they are feeling. Accept how they feel and give them comfort.
source_text: Your child will look to you for support and reassurance. Listen to your children when they share how they are feeling. Accept how they feel and give them comfort.

text: 2. Share your own feelings
source_text: 2. Share your own feelings

text: When you share your own feelings with your children, you help them recognise their own feelings. It can also help your children learn self-discipline and to understand their own feelings.
source_text: When you share your own feelings with your children, you help them recognise their own feelings. It can also help your children learn self-discipline and to understand their own feelings.

text: 3. Help your child learn how to talk about feelings
source_text: 3. Help your child learn how to talk about feelings

text: There are 6 basic emotions: Happy, Sad, Angry, Disgusted, Surprised, and Afraid. Even babies can feel and express these emotions. As children get older, they learn to identify lots of other emotions, like excited, frustrated, proud, lonely, peaceful, guilty, or confused.
source_text: There are 6 basic emotions: Happy, Sad, Angry, Disgusted, Surprised, and Afraid. Even babies can feel and express these emotions. As children get older, they learn to identify lots of other emotions, like excited, frustrated, proud, lonely, peaceful, guilty, or confused.

text: 4. Talking about difficult emotions
source_text: 4. Talking about difficult emotions

text: It is normal to have difficulty talking about and expressing emotions and feelings. Many of us were told not to cry when we were sad or laugh when we were happy. This may be especially the case for boys and men.
source_text: It is normal to have difficulty talking about and expressing emotions and feelings. Many of us were told not to cry when we were sad or laugh when we were happy. This may be especially the case for boys and men.

text: 5. Notice the positive emotions
source_text: 5. Notice the positive emotions

text: Talking about feelings can help children manage anger, disappointment, and frustration. It can also help your child be more aware of positive emotions such as a sense of peace, happiness, or calmness. It can also allow children to appreciate a beautiful moment or feeling of love!
source_text: Talking about feelings can help children manage anger, disappointment, and frustration. It can also help your child be more aware of positive emotions such as a sense of peace, happiness, or calmness. It can also allow children to appreciate a beautiful moment or feeling of love!

text: 6. Show your child that you care
source_text: 6. Show your child that you care

text: Use physical and verbal support to make your child feel accepted and loved. A hug or saying, "I understand," can mean a lot. Remind your child that you are there for them and that they can always talk to you.
source_text: Use physical and verbal support to make your child feel accepted and loved. A hug or saying, "I understand," can mean a lot. Remind your child that you are there for them and that they can always talk to you.

text: But we all have the same feelings, and  we can learn how to become aware of our own emotions, to experience them in our body, and to communicate about them.
source_text: But we all have the same feelings, and  we can learn how to become aware of our own emotions, to experience them in our body, and to communicate about them.

text: Ignore negative attention seeking and demanding behaviours like whining or tantrums. Your child’s behaviour might at first get worse, but with time they will learn that it does not work. Be consistent and patient. And make sure that you are also giving your child plenty of positive attention at other times. You can do it!

text: Here's a video to help you manage your child's temper tantrums.

text: Here are 6 steps on how we can reduce negative attention seeking and demanding behaviours like tantrums using what we call Ignore:
source_text: Here are 6 steps on how we can reduce negative attention seeking and demanding behaviours like tantrums using what we call Ignore:

text: 1. Try to redirect your child’s attention
source_text: 1. Try to redirect your child’s attention

text: 2. Make sure it is a behaviour you can ignore
source_text: 2. Make sure it is a behaviour you can ignore

text: 3. Ignore the behaviour not your child
source_text: 3. Ignore the behaviour not your child

text: 4. Praise your child immediately for the next positive behaviour
source_text: 4. Praise your child immediately for the next positive behaviour

text: 5. Be consistent when ignoring
source_text: 5. Be consistent when ignoring

text: 6. Make sure you are giving your child plenty of positive attention at other times.
source_text: 6. Make sure you are giving your child plenty of positive attention at other times.

text: To learn more about one of these tips, type "1" to "6". You can also type "N" to move on.
source_text: To learn more about one of these tips, type "1" to "6". You can also type "N" to move on.

text: Well done! You have added another skill to your Parenting Toolkit.
source_text: Well done! You have added another skill to your Parenting Toolkit.

text: Ignoring negative attention seeking and demanding behaviours is not easy. But if you are patient and give it time, it really works. You can do this!
source_text: Ignoring negative attention seeking and demanding behaviours is not easy. But if you are patient and give it time, it really works. You can do this!

text: 1. Try to redirect your child's attention
source_text: 1. Try to redirect your child's attention

text: When they start demanding for something or whining, first try to redirect them to a positive behaviour or activity. Praise them for that positive behaviour!
source_text: When they start demanding for something or whining, first try to redirect them to a positive behaviour or activity. Praise them for that positive behaviour!

text: 2. Make sure it is a behaviour you can ignore
source_text: 2. Make sure it is a behaviour you can ignore

text: These are behaviours like whining, demanding, showing off, tantrums, and lots of other negative attention seeking and demanding behaviours that might make us think of the child as a bad child. But there are no bad children, only difficult behaviours!
source_text: These are behaviours like whining, demanding, showing off, tantrums, and lots of other negative attention seeking and demanding behaviours that might make us think of the child as a bad child. But there are no bad children, only difficult behaviours!

text: 3. Ignore the behaviour not your child.
source_text: 3. Ignore the behaviour not your child.

text: Ignoring behaviour means removing physical and verbal attention. You should still be aware of what your child is doing.
source_text: Ignoring behaviour means removing physical and verbal attention. You should still be aware of what your child is doing.

text: When you ignore your child's behaviour (but not your child!), your child learns that the demanding behaviour will not work.
source_text: When you ignore your child's behaviour (but not your child!), your child learns that the demanding behaviour will not work.

text: If we respond to these behaviours, our children learn that this behaviour will get them attention. They sometimes also learn that if they increase the demand, they will get their way.
source_text: If we respond to these behaviours, our children learn that this behaviour will get them attention. They sometimes also learn that if they increase the demand, they will get their way.

text: This takes time AND patience. Normally your child will try to test you and behave worse. This is a good time to Take a Pause and Keep Calm.
source_text: This takes time AND patience. Normally your child will try to test you and behave worse. This is a good time to Take a Pause and Keep Calm.

text: For example, if your child whines for sweets at the store, you might initially say “no” but then give in to your child when they start to have a tantrum. This happens to all of us!
source_text: For example, if your child whines for sweets at the store, you might initially say “no” but then give in to your child when they start to have a tantrum. This happens to all of us!

text: 4. Praise your child immediately for the next positive behaviour
source_text: 4. Praise your child immediately for the next positive behaviour

text: Having a tantrum can be just as traumatic and difficult for your child as it is for you. Make sure you give your child plenty of positive attention and love as soon as they have calmed down.
source_text: Having a tantrum can be just as traumatic and difficult for your child as it is for you. Make sure you give your child plenty of positive attention and love as soon as they have calmed down.

text: 6. Make sure you are giving your child plenty of positive attention at other times
source_text: 6. Make sure you are giving your child plenty of positive attention at other times

text: Children need attention. If children get plenty of attention for just being themselves, as well as for the “good” things that they do, it helps them to feel good about themselves, and they do more of what they are asked.
source_text: Children need attention. If children get plenty of attention for just being themselves, as well as for the “good” things that they do, it helps them to feel good about themselves, and they do more of what they are asked.

text: 5. Be consistent when ignoring
source_text: 5. Be consistent when ignoring

text: Your child's behaviour might continue to get worse.  It is important that you continue to ignore the behaviour.
source_text: Your child's behaviour might continue to get worse.  It is important that you continue to ignore the behaviour.

text: Often, your child's response will grow more agitated when you start ignoring a specific behaviour as your child tries to test your resolve.
source_text: Often, your child's response will grow more agitated when you start ignoring a specific behaviour as your child tries to test your resolve.

text: At this time, it is more important that you involve your child in a positive activity instead of talking about what just happened. You can do that later like at night or the next day. Right now your child needs love.
source_text: At this time, it is more important that you involve your child in a positive activity instead of talking about what just happened. You can do that later like at night or the next day. Right now your child needs love.

text: Remember you can always type "Help" if you ever want more parenting tips or support.
source_text: Remember you can always type "Help" if you ever want more parenting tips or support.

text: If you find yourself ignoring your child's behaviour a lot, it is either because you are not being consistent (sometimes ignoring and sometimes giving in) OR you are not spending enough positive time with your child. One-on-One Time is super important!
source_text: If you find yourself ignoring your child's behaviour a lot, it is either because you are not being consistent (sometimes ignoring and sometimes giving in) OR you are not spending enough positive time with your child. One-on-One Time is super important!

text: Try to remain consistent. Over time, your child will learn that the demanding behaviour no longer works.
source_text: Try to remain consistent. Over time, your child will learn that the demanding behaviour no longer works.

text: Challenges are stressful. But problem-solving can really help. There are 6 basic steps for problem solving:
source_text: Challenges are stressful. But problem-solving can really help. There are 6 basic steps for problem solving:

text: 1. Identify the problem
source_text: 1. Identify the problem

text: 2. Think of possible solutions
source_text: 2. Think of possible solutions

text: 3. Figure out what the results of each solution would be
source_text: 3. Figure out what the results of each solution would be

text: 4. Choose one solution
source_text: 4. Choose one solution

text: 5. Try it out!
source_text: 5. Try it out!

text: 6. Did it work? Great! If it did not work, then try another solution

text: When something bad happens, we often get upset and blame our children. But what they really need is someone to help them work through their problems.

text: Take a Pause! Become aware of anger and stress. Take a deep breath or count to 10 before you react. Then respond in a calmer way.

text: Try to find solutions together:

text: • Allow your teen to express how they feel and accept their feelings.

text: That's okay! You can always type "Help" if you want to receive more tips about how to manage your child's behaviour.
source_text: That's okay! You can always type "Help" if you want to receive more tips about how to manage your child's behaviour.

text: Here's a video that helps you redirect your child's behaviour when they misbehave.
source_text: Here's a video that helps you redirect your child's behaviour when they misbehave.

text: Keep it positive. It is normal to want to say something about your child's negative behaviour, like “Don’t whine,” or “Stop running in the house.” Instead, just say something that you want your child to do, like "Speak with a calm voice," or "Remember to walk inside the house."
source_text: Keep it positive. It is normal to want to say something about your child's negative behaviour, like “Don’t whine,” or “Stop running in the house.” Instead, just say something that you want your child to do, like "Speak with a calm voice," or "Remember to walk inside the house."

text: If your baby is starting to crawl or walk, you can also redirect them by physically picking them up and focusing their attention on something else interesting. Use a lively and cheerful voice!
source_text: If your baby is starting to crawl or walk, you can also redirect them by physically picking them up and focusing their attention on something else interesting. Use a lively and cheerful voice!

text: Well done! You have added another tool to your Parenting Toolkit. Remember that redirecting your children only works before or at the beginning of a bad behaviour.
source_text: Well done! You have added another tool to your Parenting Toolkit. Remember that redirecting your children only works before or at the beginning of a bad behaviour.

text: You can also always type "Help" for more tips.
source_text: You can also always type "Help" for more tips.

text: Remember you can always type "Help" if you ever want more parenting tips or support. Chat to you later!
source_text: Remember you can always type "Help" if you ever want more parenting tips or support. Chat to you later!

text: When something bad happens, we often get upset and blame our children. But what they really need is someone to help them work through their problems.
source_text: When something bad happens, we often get upset and blame our children. But what they really need is someone to help them work through their problems.

text: Take a Pause! Become aware of anger and stress. Take a deep breath or count to 10 before you react. Then respond in a calmer way.
source_text: Take a Pause! Become aware of anger and stress. Take a deep breath or count to 10 before you react. Then respond in a calmer way.

text: 2. Try to stay calm when giving the consequence.
source_text: 2. Try to stay calm when giving the consequence.

text: These behaviours can take the form of whining, demanding, showing off, tantrums, and lots of other negative attention seeking and demanding behaviours that might make us think of the child as a bad child.
source_text: These behaviours can take the form of whining, demanding, showing off, tantrums, and lots of other negative attention seeking and demanding behaviours that might make us think of the child as a bad child.

text: 3. Make sure you can follow through with the consequence. For example, taking away a teenager’s phone for a week is hard to enforce. Taking it away for one hour is more realistic.
source_text: 3. Make sure you can follow through with the consequence. For example, taking away a teenager’s phone for a week is hard to enforce. Taking it away for one hour is more realistic.

text: But there are no bad children, only difficult behaviours!
source_text: But there are no bad children, only difficult behaviours!

text: Try to find solutions together:
source_text: Try to find solutions together:

text: 1. Allow your teen to express how they feel and accept their feelings.
source_text: 1. Allow your teen to express how they feel and accept their feelings.

text: 2. Try to listen to your teen and see things from their perspective.
source_text: 2. Try to listen to your teen and see things from their perspective.

text: 3. Thank your teen for being open and trusting you
source_text: 3. Thank your teen for being open and trusting you

text: 4. Once the consequence is over, give your child a chance to do something good, and praise them for it.
source_text: 4. Once the consequence is over, give your child a chance to do something good, and praise them for it.

text: If we respond to these behaviours, our children learn that this behaviour will get them attention – it is like an attention reward for bad behaviour. They sometimes also learn that if they increase the demand, they will get their way. This happens to all of us!
source_text: If we respond to these behaviours, our children learn that this behaviour will get them attention – it is like an attention reward for bad behaviour. They sometimes also learn that if they increase the demand, they will get their way. This happens to all of us!

text: Consequences can also be used when your children forget a household rule, like going to bed at a certain hour or doing schoolwork before T.V. For example, you can tell your child that if they do not do their schoolwork before dinner, they cannot watch their favourite T.V. show that evening.
source_text: Consequences can also be used when your children forget a household rule, like going to bed at a certain hour or doing schoolwork before T.V. For example, you can tell your child that if they do not do their schoolwork before dinner, they cannot watch their favourite T.V. show that evening.

text: Well done! You have added another skill to your Parenting Toolkit. Helping your teen learn how to solve problems will be something they will take with them the rest of their lives. What a gift!
source_text: Well done! You have added another skill to your Parenting Toolkit. Helping your teen learn how to solve problems will be something they will take with them the rest of their lives. What a gift!

text: For example, if your child whines for sweets at the store, you might initially say “no” but then give in to your child when they start to have a tantrum
source_text: For example, if your child whines for sweets at the store, you might initially say “no” but then give in to your child when they start to have a tantrum

text: Here are some examples of behaviours and possible consequences:
source_text: Here are some examples of behaviours and possible consequences:

text: Fighting with siblings -> Take 1 minute pause in separate parts of the room
source_text: Fighting with siblings -> Take 1 minute pause in separate parts of the room

text: Talking rudely to elders -> Write a letter of apology
source_text: Talking rudely to elders -> Write a letter of apology

text: Using gadget over the limit -> No gadget use the next day
source_text: Using gadget over the limit -> No gadget use the next day

text: Sound familiar? But there is an answer! We call it Ignore. And here are 4 steps on how to do it!
source_text: Sound familiar? But there is an answer! We call it Ignore. And here are 4 steps on how to do it!

text: 1. Try to redirect your child's attention to something new when they demand something from you or are trying to get negative attention.
source_text: 1. Try to redirect your child's attention to something new when they demand something from you or are trying to get negative attention.

text: Forgetting safe distancing rules -> Need to hold my hand for 10 minutes (kids)
source_text: Forgetting safe distancing rules -> Need to hold my hand for 10 minutes (kids)

text: Forgetting safe distancing rules -> Cannot see friends for a day (teen)
source_text: Forgetting safe distancing rules -> Cannot see friends for a day (teen)

text: Refusing to put away toys -> Cannot play with them after dinner (or next hour)
source_text: Refusing to put away toys -> Cannot play with them after dinner (or next hour)

text: 2. If your child persists, ignore your child's behaviour. You could still be aware of what your child is doing while ignoring.
source_text: 2. If your child persists, ignore your child's behaviour. You could still be aware of what your child is doing while ignoring.

text: In summary, consequences should be...
source_text: In summary, consequences should be...

text: 1. Realistic: Consider the age of your child
source_text: 1. Realistic: Consider the age of your child

text: 2. Immediate: Give them as soon as possible
source_text: 2. Immediate: Give them as soon as possible

text: 3. Fair: Make sure the consequence is not too harsh
source_text: 3. Fair: Make sure the consequence is not too harsh

text: 4. Consistent: Make sure you can follow through if you have to
source_text: 4. Consistent: Make sure you can follow through if you have to

text: 5. The last resort: Try to encourage the positive behaviour to happen more often!
source_text: 5. The last resort: Try to encourage the positive behaviour to happen more often!

text: 3. Your child's behaviour might continue to get worse.  It is important that you continue to ignore the behaviour.
source_text: 3. Your child's behaviour might continue to get worse.  It is important that you continue to ignore the behaviour.

text: 4. When the behaviour ends, immediately redirect your child to a positive behaviour and praise them.
source_text: 4. When the behaviour ends, immediately redirect your child to a positive behaviour and praise them.

text: When you ignore your child's behaviour (but not your child!), your child learns that the demanding behaviour will not work.
source_text: When you ignore your child's behaviour (but not your child!), your child learns that the demanding behaviour will not work.

text: Well done! You have added another skill to your Parenting Toolkit! Using consequences can help teach children self-discipline, independence, decision-making, and responsibility. They help children learn that their actions will have an impact on themselves and others. It is an important step to prepare them for their life outside of the family as they get older.
source_text: Well done! You have added another skill to your Parenting Toolkit! Using consequences can help teach children self-discipline, independence, decision-making, and responsibility. They help children learn that their actions will have an impact on themselves and others. It is an important step to prepare them for their life outside of the family as they get older.

text: This takes time AND patience. Normally the behaviour will get worse because your child will try to test your resolve. This is a good time to Take a Pause and Keep Calm.
source_text: This takes time AND patience. Normally the behaviour will get worse because your child will try to test your resolve. This is a good time to Take a Pause and Keep Calm.

text: It sometimes gets worse before it gets better. Often, your child's response will grow more agitated when you start ignoring a specific  behaviour as your child tries to test your resolve.
source_text: It sometimes gets worse before it gets better. Often, your child's response will grow more agitated when you start ignoring a specific  behaviour as your child tries to test your resolve.

text: Try to remain consistent and calm (you can even Take a Pause). Over time, your child will learn that the demanding behaviour no longer works.
source_text: Try to remain consistent and calm (you can even Take a Pause). Over time, your child will learn that the demanding behaviour no longer works.

text: In summary:
source_text: In summary:

text: 1. Try to redirect your child’s attention before ignoring
source_text: 1. Try to redirect your child’s attention before ignoring

text: 2. Only ignore negative attention seeking and demanding behaviours like whining and tantrums
source_text: 2. Only ignore negative attention seeking and demanding behaviours like whining and tantrums

text: 3. Ignoring behaviour means removing physical and verbal attention
source_text: 3. Ignoring behaviour means removing physical and verbal attention

text: 4. Praise your child immediately for the next positive behaviour
source_text: 4. Praise your child immediately for the next positive behaviour

text: 5. Be consistent when ignoring
source_text: 5. Be consistent when ignoring

text: 6. Make sure you are giving your child plenty of positive attention and One-on-One Time
source_text: 6. Make sure you are giving your child plenty of positive attention and One-on-One Time

text: Well done! You have added another skill to your Parenting Toolkit. Having a tantrum can be just as traumatic and difficult for your child as it is for you. Make sure you give your child plenty of positive attention and love when they have calmed down. Be patient. This is not easy. But you can do this!
source_text: Well done! You have added another skill to your Parenting Toolkit. Having a tantrum can be just as traumatic and difficult for your child as it is for you. Make sure you give your child plenty of positive attention and love when they have calmed down. Be patient. This is not easy. But you can do this!

text: Here's a video to help you create daily routines with your children.

text: Daily routines, such as time for schoolwork, play, meals, and sleep, can help our children feel safe and secure. They also give our children a sense of security.
source_text: Daily routines, such as time for schoolwork, play, meals, and sleep, can help our children feel safe and secure. They also give our children a sense of security.

text: Here are 4 simple tips that you can use when establishing routines with your children:
source_text: Here are 4 simple tips that you can use when establishing routines with your children:

text: 1. Give one instruction at a time
source_text: 1. Give one instruction at a time

text: 2. Use transition warnings to help move from one activity to the next one
source_text: 2. Use transition warnings to help move from one activity to the next one

text: 3. Create regular eating and sleeping times
source_text: 3. Create regular eating and sleeping times

text: 4. Involve your teen in creating daily routines
source_text: 4. Involve your teen in creating daily routines

text: 1. Help your younger children learn routines by taking them through the activity step by step. Give one instruction at a time. Praise them each time they follow!
source_text: 1. Help your younger children learn routines by taking them through the activity step by step. Give one instruction at a time. Praise them each time they follow!

text: 4. Involve your teen in creating daily plans. Set goals and rewards together. Let them plan when they do schoolwork and when they can relax!

text: 2. Transition warnings can also be very helpful. They give your child some time to prepare for the next activity: "In 5 minutes it will be time to pack up the toys before bedtime…"
source_text: 2. Transition warnings can also be very helpful. They give your child some time to prepare for the next activity: "In 5 minutes it will be time to pack up the toys before bedtime…"

text: 3. Regular eating and sleeping times are especially important for babies. Not enough sleep can make your child cranky, irritable, and short tempered.

text: Here are some tips for how to help your child prepare for bedtime:
source_text: Here are some tips for how to help your child prepare for bedtime:

text: • Try to have regular bedtimes each day as much as possible.

text: • Try to make it quiet and the lights in the room dim.

text: • Spend some time with your child. You can sing a lullaby or tell a calm story.

text: • Give your child a hug and kiss goodnight before leaving the room.

text: 1. Follow your child’s interest
source_text: 1. Follow your child’s interest

text: Talk about what interests your child. When your child shows interest in a picture (pointing, patting, looking), use this as a chance to talk about what has attracted your child’s interest
source_text: Talk about what interests your child. When your child shows interest in a picture (pointing, patting, looking), use this as a chance to talk about what has attracted your child’s interest

text: 2. Use a lively voice
source_text: 2. Use a lively voice

text: Speak with a lively or animated voice. This will help to keep the child’s attention on the book.
source_text: Speak with a lively or animated voice. This will help to keep the child’s attention on the book.

text: Well done! You have added another tool to your Parenting Toolbox! Sharing books with your child will help them to learn to speak, think and focus better. It will also help them to get along with others better, by helping them understand about feelings. Chat to you later!
source_text: Well done! You have added another tool to your Parenting Toolbox! Sharing books with your child will help them to learn to speak, think and focus better. It will also help them to get along with others better, by helping them understand about feelings. Chat to you later!

text: 3. Pointing and naming
source_text: 3. Pointing and naming

text: Pointing to and naming an object or person in the book will help your child learn new words. Children learn through repetition, so repeat the word and look for other opportunities to use the word (in the book or elsewhere).
source_text: Pointing to and naming an object or person in the book will help your child learn new words. Children learn through repetition, so repeat the word and look for other opportunities to use the word (in the book or elsewhere).

text: 4. Be positive and supportive
source_text: 4. Be positive and supportive

text: Always respond positively to whatever your child says about the pictures. For example, if your child points to a red apple and says “Tomato”, you can say “Yes, you’re right, it’s red - it's an apple!”
source_text: Always respond positively to whatever your child says about the pictures. For example, if your child points to a red apple and says “Tomato”, you can say “Yes, you’re right, it’s red - it's an apple!”

text: If your child knows a word and can say that word, ask “What’s that?” and give them the opportunity to say the word and point to it.
source_text: If your child knows a word and can say that word, ask “What’s that?” and give them the opportunity to say the word and point to it.

text: 5. Making actions and links
source_text: 5. Making actions and links

text: Connect things in the book with familiar things in your child’s world. For example, if the baby in the book is wearing shoes, ask your child to point out their own shoes. If someone in the book is waving, you and your child can do the same.
source_text: Connect things in the book with familiar things in your child’s world. For example, if the baby in the book is wearing shoes, ask your child to point out their own shoes. If someone in the book is waving, you and your child can do the same.

text: 6. Talking about feelings
source_text: 6. Talking about feelings

text: Books are a great way for children to learn more about feelings. You can use your face and voice to help them understand emotion words like happy, sad, angry, or scared. You can use what is happening in the book to talk about your child’s own feelings, and why other people might feel a certain way.
source_text: Books are a great way for children to learn more about feelings. You can use your face and voice to help them understand emotion words like happy, sad, angry, or scared. You can use what is happening in the book to talk about your child’s own feelings, and why other people might feel a certain way.

text: 7. Babies and Books!
source_text: 7. Babies and Books!

text: Even very young babies enjoy book-sharing and looking at the pictures together with a parent or caregiver. In fact, regular book-sharing helps their development and learning. And it is okay for them to put the book in their mouth - they are exploring!
source_text: Even very young babies enjoy book-sharing and looking at the pictures together with a parent or caregiver. In fact, regular book-sharing helps their development and learning. And it is okay for them to put the book in their mouth - they are exploring!

text: Here are some examples!
source_text: Here are some examples!

text: “Look, she is smiling. Why do you think she is smiling? What made you smile today?”
source_text: “Look, she is smiling. Why do you think she is smiling? What made you smile today?”

text: “The monkey is sad because he is all on his own. Can you remember when you were last sad?”
source_text: “The monkey is sad because he is all on his own. Can you remember when you were last sad?”

text: “That tiger looks angry. Why do you think he is angry? Do you remember when I got angry this morning?”
source_text: “That tiger looks angry. Why do you think he is angry? Do you remember when I got angry this morning?”

text: You can use books and stories to help talk with children about topics related to COVID-19 (such as getting sick, not going to school or work, staying indoors, feeling worried) and help them think about how this makes them feel.
source_text: You can use books and stories to help talk with children about topics related to COVID-19 (such as getting sick, not going to school or work, staying indoors, feeling worried) and help them think about how this makes them feel.

text: Chat to you later!
source_text: Chat to you later!

text: We all make mistakes! The more consistent we are with our consequences, the more likely our children will choose to behave positively in the future.
source_text: We all make mistakes! The more consistent we are with our consequences, the more likely our children will choose to behave positively in the future.

text: This is hard to remember! When you give your child a choice, you teach your child decision making skills. It does not always work, but when it does, it helps avoid having to give a consequence and a difficult situation later!
source_text: This is hard to remember! When you give your child a choice, you teach your child decision making skills. It does not always work, but when it does, it helps avoid having to give a consequence and a difficult situation later!

text: Check to make sure your consequence is fair and reasonable. For example, if your child refuses to help put away their toys, try prohibiting playing with them for an evening instead of threatening to throw them away.
source_text: Check to make sure your consequence is fair and reasonable. For example, if your child refuses to help put away their toys, try prohibiting playing with them for an evening instead of threatening to throw them away.

text: When we take a pause before responding, it helps us to calm down and respond better. Next time your child or teen makes you angry, try to take a pause first. Even a few deep breaths can make a big difference!
source_text: When we take a pause before responding, it helps us to calm down and respond better. Next time your child or teen makes you angry, try to take a pause first. Even a few deep breaths can make a big difference!

text: Sometimes our children will react in a negative way when receiving a consequence. If your child is younger than 9 and throws a tantrum, you should ignore your child's behaviour until it is over.  If your child is older, you might need to walk away until they calm down.
source_text: Sometimes our children will react in a negative way when receiving a consequence. If your child is younger than 9 and throws a tantrum, you should ignore your child's behaviour until it is over.  If your child is older, you might need to walk away until they calm down.

text: If you find yourself always having to give consequences to your children for behaving badly, you might need to spend more positive time with them. It will help them feel more loved and secure...and you less stressed!
source_text: If you find yourself always having to give consequences to your children for behaving badly, you might need to spend more positive time with them. It will help them feel more loved and secure...and you less stressed!

text: Sharing emotions – especially the difficult ones – sets an important example for your child or teen! It actually makes everyone in the family stronger, because you can understand and support each other better.
source_text: Sharing emotions – especially the difficult ones – sets an important example for your child or teen! It actually makes everyone in the family stronger, because you can understand and support each other better.

text: Starting a new thing is always difficult at first. Give yourselves some time to get used to it, and keep giving the good example by noticing and sharing emotions. Over time, your child or teen will learn to do the same – and they will feel even more loved and cared for.
source_text: Starting a new thing is always difficult at first. Give yourselves some time to get used to it, and keep giving the good example by noticing and sharing emotions. Over time, your child or teen will learn to do the same – and they will feel even more loved and cared for.

text: Sharing emotions is about explaining how you are feeling so your child or teen is aware and learns to do the same. You can choose how much detail you want to share about the situation. It’s up to you! You can also choose to answer questions later: “I am feeling angry/stressed now, can you please give me some time? We can talk about this more tonight”.
source_text: Sharing emotions is about explaining how you are feeling so your child or teen is aware and learns to do the same. You can choose how much detail you want to share about the situation. It’s up to you! You can also choose to answer questions later: “I am feeling angry/stressed now, can you please give me some time? We can talk about this more tonight”.

text: It’s okay to not want to share at that time. Find some time later on when you feel calmer to explain so that everyone can understand.
source_text: It’s okay to not want to share at that time. Find some time later on when you feel calmer to explain so that everyone can understand.

text: Being specific is not rude or insensitive, it really helps others understand you clearly and prevents confusion in the family. Emotions like anger and stress are part of our lives. All we need to do when we feel angry and stressed is know how to handle it by taking a few deep breaths before responding.
source_text: Being specific is not rude or insensitive, it really helps others understand you clearly and prevents confusion in the family. Emotions like anger and stress are part of our lives. All we need to do when we feel angry and stressed is know how to handle it by taking a few deep breaths before responding.

text: I know, it can be really difficult to stay calm when our children are whining or having a tantrum. Try to think of something that you can do to help like taking a pause. You can do this!
source_text: I know, it can be really difficult to stay calm when our children are whining or having a tantrum. Try to think of something that you can do to help like taking a pause. You can do this!

text: If you are finding that you are ignoring your child's behaviour a lot, then your child is probably not getting enough positive attention at other times. Try to spend more One-on-One Time with your child!
source_text: If you are finding that you are ignoring your child's behaviour a lot, then your child is probably not getting enough positive attention at other times. Try to spend more One-on-One Time with your child!

text: Sometimes, our children can have very violent tantrums when they do not get their way, especially if they are used to it. Try to move your child to a place where they will not hurt themselves or others. You may need to firmly hold your child while ignoring their behaviour - but only do this if you can remain calm and  make sure you are not hurting them! Eventually, your child will calm down.
source_text: Sometimes, our children can have very violent tantrums when they do not get their way, especially if they are used to it. Try to move your child to a place where they will not hurt themselves or others. You may need to firmly hold your child while ignoring their behaviour - but only do this if you can remain calm and  make sure you are not hurting them! Eventually, your child will calm down.

text: I know, it is hard to be consistent! If you ignore a behaviour only some of the time, your child will think it might help them get their way. The more consistent you are, the less they will do it.

text: Routines will make your children feel safe and secure. Try to have regular mealtimes and bedtimes. Remember to schedule One-on-One time with your children, too!
source_text: Routines will make your children feel safe and secure. Try to have regular mealtimes and bedtimes. Remember to schedule One-on-One time with your children, too!

text: Did you know that teens actually like having responsibilities? It makes them feel more independent and grown up. Allow your teen to choose a special job that helps out.
source_text: Did you know that teens actually like having responsibilities? It makes them feel more independent and grown up. Allow your teen to choose a special job that helps out.

text: Routines will make your children feel safe and secure. Try to have regular mealtimes and bedtimes. Remember to schedule One-on-One time with your children, too!

text: When you teach your children about safe distancing, you keep your whole family safe. You keep others safe, too!
source_text: When you teach your children about safe distancing, you keep your whole family safe. You keep others safe, too!

text: As your teen shows more responsibility, you can also give them extra privileges. Try to share responsibilities equally amongst women/men and girls/boys. Praise your teen whenever they do their job!
source_text: As your teen shows more responsibility, you can also give them extra privileges. Try to share responsibilities equally amongst women/men and girls/boys. Praise your teen whenever they do their job!

text: You can even make safe distancing into a game where children earn points for keeping at least 1 metre away from others in public. The one with the most points can win a simple, free reward like extra One-on-One Time

text: It is always important when establishing rules and routines  as a family to consider the age of each child, so you can come up with age-appropriate routines. This is most important for bedtime, time to come home/play, household chores.

text: We should always remember that children learn best from us. The more we follow the rules, they more they will follow the rules too. You can adjust the rule to make sure that it is realistic for everyone to follow it, considering their responsibilities (for example school or work activities).

You can adjust the rule to make sure that it is realistic for everyone to follow it, considering their responsibilities (for example school or work activities).

text: Step 5. Support your child when they go back to school
source_text: Step 5. Support your child when they go back to school

text: Tell your child that it is okay to feel scared or worried about going back to school. Allow your child to share how they are feeling. It is also normal if your child behaves different to their usual behaviour. Discuss how going to school might be different and how they can protect themselves from COVID-19. Ask them how their day went and support them if they experienced any difficulties.
source_text: Tell your child that it is okay to feel scared or worried about going back to school. Allow your child to share how they are feeling. It is also normal if your child behaves different to their usual behaviour. Discuss how going to school might be different and how they can protect themselves from COVID-19. Ask them how their day went and support them if they experienced any difficulties.

text: Step 3. Remember that you are a parent NOT a substitute teacher!
source_text: Step 3. Remember that you are a parent NOT a substitute teacher!

text: Your role is to support your child by creating a space to learn. You do not need to know all the answers. Help them explore their interests and ask questions. Go at your child's pace and be patient with yourself.
source_text: Your role is to support your child by creating a space to learn. You do not need to know all the answers. Help them explore their interests and ask questions. Go at your child's pace and be patient with yourself.

text: Step 1. Create a routine around learning and schoolwork
source_text: Step 1. Create a routine around learning and schoolwork

text: Make a daily plan with your child for when they can spend time doing educational activities. This can include structured schoolwork and other activities online, reading, writing, or arts. Allow flexibility and time for play and relaxation too.
source_text: Make a daily plan with your child for when they can spend time doing educational activities. This can include structured schoolwork and other activities online, reading, writing, or arts. Allow flexibility and time for play and relaxation too.

text: Step 2. Make learning fun and playful
source_text: Step 2. Make learning fun and playful

text: Children learn best when learning is fun! Try to find ways to make learning playful to keep your child interested and engaged. Type "Help" if you ever need any fun ideas!
source_text: Children learn best when learning is fun! Try to find ways to make learning playful to keep your child interested and engaged. Type "Help" if you ever need any fun ideas!

text: Step 4. Stay connected with your child's school and teachers
source_text: Step 4. Stay connected with your child's school and teachers

text: Find out how to stay in touch with your children’s teacher or school to stay informed, ask questions and get more guidance. If you are struggling or know someone who is struggling with school work or the home situation, please discuss this with a teacher that you feel close to. Parent groups or community groups can also be a good way to support each other with your home schooling.

text: Step 4. Share the load
source_text: Step 4. Share the load

text: Looking after children and other family members is difficult, but it’s much easier when responsibilities are shared. Try to share household chores, childcare, and other tasks equally amongst family members
source_text: Looking after children and other family members is difficult, but it’s much easier when responsibilities are shared. Try to share household chores, childcare, and other tasks equally amongst family members

text: Step 5. Take care of yourself
source_text: Step 5. Take care of yourself

text: Create a schedule for time “on” and time “off” with other adults in your household. It is okay to ask for help when you are feeling tired or stressed so that you can take a break
source_text: Create a schedule for time “on” and time “off” with other adults in your household. It is okay to ask for help when you are feeling tired or stressed so that you can take a break

text: Step 6. Do nice things together as a family
source_text: Step 6. Do nice things together as a family

text: Let each family member take turns choosing a whole family activity. Find ways to spend time alone with other adults in your home, too!
source_text: Let each family member take turns choosing a whole family activity. Find ways to spend time alone with other adults in your home, too!

text: Step 1. Be a model of behaviour for your kids
source_text: Step 1. Be a model of behaviour for your kids

text: How we talk and behave in front of our children is a big influence on how they behave too! Try to talk kindly to everyone in the family, adults and children.
source_text: How we talk and behave in front of our children is a big influence on how they behave too! Try to talk kindly to everyone in the family, adults and children.

text: Step 2. Use positive language. It works!
source_text: Step 2. Use positive language. It works!

text: Tell others what you want them to do instead of what you don’t want them to do: Instead of “Stop shouting,” try “Please speak more quietly”
source_text: Tell others what you want them to do instead of what you don’t want them to do: Instead of “Stop shouting,” try “Please speak more quietly”

text: Step 3. Be a great listener
source_text: Step 3. Be a great listener

text: Listen to others when they are talking with you. Be open and show them that you hear what they are saying. It can help to summarise what you have heard before responding: “What I hear you saying is…”
source_text: Listen to others when they are talking with you. Be open and show them that you hear what they are saying. It can help to summarise what you have heard before responding: “What I hear you saying is…”

text: Decide to take a break from arguing when you see arguments building up, and go into another room or outside if you can.
source_text: Decide to take a break from arguing when you see arguments building up, and go into another room or outside if you can.

text: You can always type "Help" if you need an activity to help you with stress.
source_text: You can always type "Help" if you need an activity to help you with stress.

text: Praise others to make them feel appreciated and good about themselves. Simple words like, “Thank you for clearing the dinner,” or “Thank you for watching the baby” can make a big difference
source_text: Praise others to make them feel appreciated and good about themselves. Simple words like, “Thank you for clearing the dinner,” or “Thank you for watching the baby” can make a big difference

text: Here are 5 tips that can help you keep yourself safe online:
source_text: Here are 5 tips that can help you keep yourself safe online:

text: 1. Learn about the risks and dangers
source_text: 1. Learn about the risks and dangers

text: 2. Quick tech fixes
source_text: 2. Quick tech fixes

text: 3. Create healthy and safe online habits
source_text: 3. Create healthy and safe online habits

text: 4. Maintain privacy
source_text: 4. Maintain privacy

text: 5. Report and seek help

text: 1. Learn about risks and dangers
source_text: 1. Learn about risks and dangers

text: • Adults targeting people for sexual purposes on social media, gaming, and messaging platforms.
source_text: • Adults targeting people for sexual purposes on social media, gaming, and messaging platforms.

text: • Harmful content – like violence, hating women, hating foreigners, encouraging suicide and self-harm, misinformation, pornography
source_text: • Harmful content – like violence, hating women, hating foreigners, encouraging suicide and self-harm, misinformation, pornography

text: • Sharing personal information and sexual photos or videos.
source_text: • Sharing personal information and sexual photos or videos.

text: • Cyberbullying from other people and strangers.
source_text: • Cyberbullying from other people and strangers.

text: 5. Report and seek help
source_text: 5. Report and seek help

text: Report to INHOPE Hotlines and IWF portals to get support if you experience online violence or other things that are not acceptable.
source_text: Report to INHOPE Hotlines and IWF portals to get support if you experience online violence or other things that are not acceptable.

text: INHOPE Hotlines: https://www.inhope.org/EN#hotlineReferral
source_text: INHOPE Hotlines: https://www.inhope.org/EN#hotlineReferral

text: IWF portals: https://report.iwf.org.uk/en
source_text: IWF portals: https://report.iwf.org.uk/en

text: Child Helpline: https://www.childhelplineinternational.org/
source_text: Child Helpline: https://www.childhelplineinternational.org/

text: 4. Maintain privacy
source_text: 4. Maintain privacy

text: Keep personal information private, especially from strangers. – some people are not who they say they are!
source_text: Keep personal information private, especially from strangers. – some people are not who they say they are!

text: 2. Quick tech fixes:
source_text: 2. Quick tech fixes:

text: • Turn on SafeSearch on your browser to filter adult content.
source_text: • Turn on SafeSearch on your browser to filter adult content.

text: https://www.internetmatters.org/blog/parental-controls/entertainment-search-engines/
source_text: https://www.internetmatters.org/blog/parental-controls/entertainment-search-engines/

text: • Set up parental controls.
source_text: • Set up parental controls.

text: https://www.internetmatters.org/parental-controls/
source_text: https://www.internetmatters.org/parental-controls/

text: • Set up strict privacy settings on online apps and games.
source_text: • Set up strict privacy settings on online apps and games.

text: https://www.internetmatters.org/blog/parental-controls/social-media/
source_text: https://www.internetmatters.org/blog/parental-controls/social-media/

text: • Cover webcams when not in use.
source_text: • Cover webcams when not in use.

text: 3. Create healthy and safe online habits:
source_text: 3. Create healthy and safe online habits:

text: You can also create healthy and safe online habits like creating device-free spaces and times in your house (eating, playing, schoolwork, and sleeping).
source_text: You can also create healthy and safe online habits like creating device-free spaces and times in your house (eating, playing, schoolwork, and sleeping).

text: Remember that what goes online stays online (messages, photos, and videos).
source_text: Remember that what goes online stays online (messages, photos, and videos).
